errorsByRule.description: Variables, imports, or parameters defined but never used
require() style imports instead of ES6 imports
Variable never reassigned, should use const instead of let

unused_vars.description: Unused variables, imports, or function parameters

require_imports.description: CommonJS require() statements that should be ES6 imports

prefer_const.description: Variables that should be const instead of let

insights.message: 321 unused variable errors (96.98%) - suggests extensive code cleanup needed
insights.impact: This indicates a significant amount of dead code, unused imports, or incomplete refactoring. This can lead to larger bundle sizes, confusion for developers, and maintenance issues.

insights.message: 8 require() style imports found - should be converted to ES6 imports
insights.impact: CommonJS require() statements prevent tree-shaking and are inconsistent with modern ES6 module syntax. This affects bundle size optimization.

insights.message: File tg-bots.service.ts has 29 errors - consider refactoring
insights.impact: A single file with many errors suggests it may be doing too much or needs significant cleanup. This file should be prioritized for refactoring.

insights.message: Many test files have unused variables - likely from incomplete test setup or commented-out code
insights.impact: Test files with unused variables may indicate incomplete tests or leftover code from test development.

recommendations.action: Remove unused imports and variables throughout the codebase
details: Use IDE features or tools like ts-prune to identify unused exports
For intentionally unused variables (e.g., in catch blocks), prefix with underscore: _error
Review and remove unused function parameters
Consider using TypeScript's unused parameter prefix: _paramName
recommendations.estimatedImpact: Will reduce bundle size, improve code clarity, and make maintenance easier

recommendations.action: Convert require() statements to ES6 import statements
details: Convert: const x = require('module') to: import x from 'module'
Convert: const { a, b } = require('module') to: import { a, b } from 'module'
This enables better tree-shaking and is consistent with modern JavaScript practices
recommendations.estimatedImpact: Better bundle optimization and consistency with ES6 module system

recommendations.action: Refactor files with high error counts
details: Consider breaking large files into smaller, more focused modules
Review wallet.service.ts (18 errors) and permissions-helper.service.ts (17 errors)
recommendations.estimatedImpact: Improved code maintainability and reduced complexity

details: @ts-expect-error will error if the issue is fixed, making it safer
recommendations.estimatedImpact: Better type safety and catching of fixed type errors

recommendations.action: Use const for variables that are never reassigned
details: Change let to const in publications.router.ts line 240
This improves code clarity and prevents accidental reassignment

unusedErrorHandlers.description: Error variables in catch blocks that are never used
unusedErrorHandlers.solution: Prefix with underscore: catch (_error) or remove if not needed

unusedImports.description: Imported modules/types that are never used
unusedImports.solution: Remove unused imports or use IDE auto-remove feature

unusedFunctionParameters.description: Function parameters that are defined but never used
examples: function handler(ctx, input) { } // ctx and input unused
async function process(userId, authorId) { } // both unused
unusedFunctionParameters.solution: Remove if not needed, or prefix with underscore if required by interface

examples: const result = await someFunction(); // result never used
let userRole = getUserRole(); // userRole never used
unusedVariables.solution: Remove assignment if value is not needed, or use the variable
